sec.title: Abstract
sec.p:
Three new species of the subgenus
Lepidohelea Kieffer, 1917
of the genus
Forcipomyia
were described from the northern region of West Bengal based on morphological data.
Forcipomyia ( L .) inflatistyla
sp. n.
was collected from the Dooars region (Jayanti, near the Core area of Buxa Tiger Reserve), while two new species
F . ( L .) ranula
and
F . ( L .) sulcoa
were procured from Kalimpong in the Eastern Himalaya. Discovery of the three new species raises the total number of species of the genus
Forcipomyia
to 86 in India . A key to the Indian species of
Lepidohelea
is also provided.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The main objective of this article is to describe and illustrate three new species of the subgenus
Lepidohelea
from India . Keys to male and female Indian species of this subgenus are also provided.

sec.title: Material and Methods
sec.p:
Specimens were collected by using various types of light traps like Blacklight (8W), Yellow filament blub (40W), and Compact fluorescent lamp (27W) from northern parts of West Bengal , India ( Figs. 1A–C ). Collected specimens were preserved in 70 % ethanol and then sorted under a stereoscopic trinocular (Olympus Model, SZX16, Japan ). After sorting, the specimens were treated with a mixture of phenol–alcohol (50:50) and specimens were slide mounted following the technique of
under a stereoscopic binocular microscope ( Magnus Model, MS –24, India ). Morphology and terminology of adults follow Alwin & Szadziewsky (2013), and terminology of antennal sensilla follows
. Most of the measurements are in micrometers (µm), except for the length and width of wing which are in millimeters (mm) with ranges followed by the mean value in parentheses in case of more than two individuals and suffixed by ‘n’ indicating the number of specimens encountered in the study. Illustrations were done by a compound microscope (Wild Leitz GMBH, Portugal ) in combination with a Camera Lucida. The photographs were taken with a camera attached fluorescence microscope in a bright field (Leica DM 1000). The proposed new species were compared with allied species; new records and key construction are based on only relevant literature and type specimens.

Abbreviations with their full forms. AR —Antennal ratio,
PR
—Palpal ratio, WL —Wing length, WW —Wing width, CR —Costal ratio; TR —Tarsal ratio, HTC —Hind tibial comb

Types presently retained in the Biosystematics & Entomology Division, Department of Zoology, The University of Burdwan, West Bengal , India will be deposited in the National Zoological Collections (NZCI), Kolkata, in due course.

tp:taxon-treatment.tp:mixed-nomenclature:
Forcipomyia ( Lepidohelea ) inflatistyla
sp. n.
urn:lsid:zoobank.org:act: E93E36BA-03FF-453B-A71D-DE16E7F68F07

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Etymology. The specific name of new species
“ inflatistyla
” derives from the greatly swollen base of gonostylus.

Type Material.
Holotype ♂ , India , West Bengal , Alipurduar , Jayanti ( 26.700772°N , 89.614778°E ),
27.viii.2023
, Col. G.S. Pal.
Paratypes 5♂♂ and 4♀♀ , same data as holotype
.

sec.title: Male (n=6)
sec.p: Thorax . Scutum dark brown; scutellum combination of yellow and dark brown with 11 long bristles; upper part of pleuron pale yellowish.

Wings . Wings covered with numerous macrotrichia and scales; scale mainly distributed on costa and radius vein, first radial cell closed and second one open ( Fig. 2C ); WL 1.12–1.15 (1.14), WW 0.34–0.36 (0.35) and CR 0.47–0.50 (0.49). Halteres white.

Abdomen . Dark brown, covered with flattened scales and setae. Sternite IX 105–118 (113) long and 174–190 (182.3) wide, almost 1.6 times wider than length. Tergite IX 204–220 (211.3) long and 178–195 (187) wide, almost 0.9 times as long as wide.

sec.title: Female (n = 4)
sec.p: Overall, they are similar in body coloration, and distribution on scales and setae on body; similar shape of maxillary palp with males, but some usual sexual and other differences are stated below.
Thorax . Scutum and scutellum brown; upper part of pleuron pale brown and lower part brown. Scutellum with ten bristles.
Legs . TRI 1.31–1.38 (1.34), TRII 0.72–0.76 (0.74), TRIII 0.67–0.70 (0.68); HTC with six spines and a spur ( Fig. 2N ).

Remarks.
Forcipomyia ( L .) inflatistyla
sp. n.
differs from other known Indian species of the subgenus
Lepidohelea
owing to swollen base of gonocoxite, the blunt tip of submedian process of parameres, and two rounded, large spermathecae without neck. Males of
F . ( L .) inflatistyla
sp. n.
are little similar to the Australian species F .
( L .) adversari Debenham, 1987
based on the shape of aedeagus, poorly developed cercus and slightly bowed gonocoxite. However, it differs in protruding capitate sensilla on the maxillary palp, blunt apex of the submedian process of parameres and “U” shaped caudomedian excavation (capitate sensilla remain within sensory pit, apex of submedian process of parameres have digits like process and caudomedian excavation slightly undulated in F .
( L .) adversari
). Males of
F . ( L .) inflatistyla
sp. n.
also somewhat resemble (protruding capitate sensilla and elongated aedeagus) those of F . ( L .) articulatus Ma & Yan, in
from China . Still, it differs with F . ( L .) articulatus in much longer and inwardly directed and pointed apex of submedian process of parameres, and straight caudomedian excavation. Males of
F . ( L .) inflatistyla
sp. n.
are also similar to another Australian species F .
( L .) bullata Debenham, 1987
due to their resemblance with maxillary palp and aedeagal structure; however, it differs in the flattened apex of gonostylus, and much longer, bifurcated apex of submedian process of parameres from new one (apex of gonostylus narrow and pointed in
F . ( L .) inflatistyla
sp. n.
). Males of
F . ( L .) inflatistyla
sp. n.
appear similar in having protruding capitate sensilla of the maxillary palp to an Australian species F .
( L .) davidi Debenham, 1987
but differ in the shape of parameres, aedeagus and caudomedian excavation (submedian process of parameres long, pointed and outwardly directed, aedeagus shield shaped and caudomedian excavation roughly straight in F .
( L .) davidi
).

Females of F .
( L .) biharinathensis Pal, Chatterjee & Hazra, 2024b
have similar types of maxillary palp with
F . ( L .) inflatistyla
sp. n.
, but they differ in having single spermatheca with a long and well-developed neck (two large rounded spermathecae without neck in
F . ( L .) inflatistyla
sp. n.
). In addition, females of
F . ( L .) inflatistyla
sp. n.
share similarities with F .
( L .) bullata
having protruding capitate sensilla of maxillary palp and number of spermatheca, but the latter differ in hyaline punctation with short, stout neck of spermatheca. The females of Australian species F .
( L .) quinqueremis
described by
also resemble
F . ( L .) inflatistyla
sp. n.
having two spermathecae and similar morphometry in wing length, but
F . ( L .) inflatistyla
sp. n.
differs in hyaline punctation of spermatheca and light brown halteres.
Distribution . Only in type locality.

tp:taxon-treatment.tp:mixed-nomenclature:
Forcipomyia ( Lepidohelea ) ranula
sp. n.
urn:lsid:zoobank.org:act: 1B04CA91-A4F0-49AC-8764-9003C19582D7

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Etymology. The specific name of new species
“ ranula
” derives from the “early-stage tadpole of frog” like appearance of submedian process of the parameres.

Type Material.
Holotype ♂ , India , West Bengal , Kalimpong , Lungsel ( 27.010637°N , 88.633360°E ),
30.viii.2023
, Col. G.S. Pal.
Paratypes 7♂♂ and 5♀♀ , same data as holotype
.

sec.title: Male (n=8)
sec.p: Thorax . Scutum dark brown; scutellum with a combination of yellow and dark brown with 12 long bristles; upper part of pleuron brown.

Wings ( Fig. 3C ). Wings covered with numerous macrotrichia and scales present on costa and radius; first radial cell closed and second one open; WL 1.08–1.18 (1.13), WW 0.34–0.37 (0.35) and CR 0.46–0.49 (0.47). Halteres white.

Abdomen . Brown to dark brown. Tergites IV–VIII covered with scales and setae. Sternite IX 93–98 (95) long and 148–162 (155) wide, almost 1.6 times wider than length. Tergite IX 150–162 (157) long and 155–170 (162) wide, almost as long as wide.

sec.title: Female (n = 5)
sec.p: Overall, they similar in body coloration and distribution on scales on body with males, but some sexual and other differences stated below.
Thorax . Scutum and scutellum dark brown; pleuron pale brown to yellowish. Scutum with numerous randomly arranged setae. Scutellum with nine long setae.
Legs . TRI 1.22–1.29 (1.25), TRII 0.85–0.90 (0.87), TRIII 0.74–0.77 (0.75); HTC with eight spines and a spur ( Fig. 3N ).

Remarks. Males of
F . ( L .) ranula
sp. n.
are similar to an Indian species F .
( L .) buccina Pal, Chatterjee and Hazra, 2024b
in the shape of gonostylus and aedeagus. However, the latter species can easily be distinguished by the shape of parameres (lateral process of parameres prong horn like and submedian process knife like in
F . ( L .) buccina
). Males of
F . ( L .) ranula
sp. n.
appears similar in having a rectangular aedeagus and roughly straight caudomedian excavation to an Australian species F .
( L .) paenulata Debenham, 1987
. However, it differs by flattened ending of gonostylus and narrow lateral process of parameres (gonostylus ending with pointed tip and much wider lateral process of parameres at the distal end of F .
( L .) paenulata
).

Females of F .
( L .) maculatus Liu, Yan & Liu, 1996
from China have similar shape of the spermatheca and maxillary palp of
F . ( L .) ranula
sp. n.
but differs in wing length and AR value (wing much longer and low AR value in F .
( L .) maculatus
). Females of
F . ( L .) ranula
sp. n.
share similarity with F .
( L .) paenulata Debenham, 1987
on maxillary palp structure and number of spermathecae. However, spermathecae of the latter species possess with hyaline punctation and low PR value.
Distribution. Only from type locality.

tp:taxon-treatment.tp:mixed-nomenclature:
Forcipomyia ( Lepidohelea ) sulcoa
sp. n.
urn:lsid:zoobank.org:act: B9C7E98F-F2DE-4AA4-9B2F-CC674204CFAB

tp:treatment-sec.p:
Etymology. The specific name
“ sulcoa
” derives from a Latin word, indicating “a small groove” present in the aedeagus.

Type Material.
Holotype ♂ , India , West Bengal , Kalimpong , Paren ( 27.058592 °N , 88.864915 °E ),
08.v.2023
, Col. G.S. Pal.
Paratypes 3♂♂ and 2♀♀ , same data as holotype
.

sec.title: Male (n=4)
sec.p: Thorax . Dark brown, scutum dark brown with irregularly scattered setae, scutellum with combination of yellowbrown color.
Wings . Wing densely covered with macrotrichia ( Fig. 4C ). WL 1.00–1.04 (1.02), WW 0.31–0.33 (32) and CR 0.47–0.49 (0.48). Halteres whitish.

Abdomen . Yellowish brown to dark brown; dark flattened scales present. Sternite IX 105–111 (108) long and 180–187 (185) wide. Tergite IX 154–157 (156) long and 178–186 (183) wide; posterior margin roughly rounded.

sec.title: Female (n = 2)
sec.p: Females are similar in body coloration and distribution on scales on body with males, but some sexual and other differences stated below.
Thorax . Scutum brown to dark brown; scutellum pale brown with 10 setae; pleuron yellowish.
Wings ( Fig. 4L ). Wing densely covered with scales (especially on costa and radius veins) and macrotrichia. WL 1.08–1.10, WW 0.43–0.44 and CR 0.51–0.52.
Legs . TRI 1.34–1.36, TRII 0.86–0.88, TRIII 0.70–0.72. Hind tibial comb with seven spines and spur ( Fig. 4M ).

sec.title: Remarks
sec.p:
The
Forcipomyia sulcoa
sp. n.
differs from all known Indian species of the subgenus
Lepidohelea
in roughly square shaped aedeagus with notch in middle of the apical margin. The males of proposed new species (
F . ( L .) sulcoa
sp. n.
and F .
( L .) ansula Pal, Ghosh & Hazra, 2024a
from India have similar gonostylus shape, but the latter species have a roughly triangular aedeagus and tip of the submedian process of parameres inwardly curved. The males
F . ( L .) sulcoa
sp. n.
and F .
( L .) cerberus Debenham, 1987
have similar shaped parameres. However, it differs in blunt gonostylus, yellow banding pattern on gonocoxite and aedeagus without projection (gonostylus much pointed, gonocoxite uniformly dark brown and aedeagus with a mace shaped process in F .
( L .) cerberus
). Males of
F . ( L .) sulcoa
sp. n.
appear similar in having blunt gonostylus end, overall shape of the parameres and maxillary palp to another Australian species F .
( L .) lagoenae Debenham, 1987
but differs in the shape of aedeagus (aedeagus long, triangular).

Females
F . ( L .) ansula
have similar type of spermatheca and overall body coloration to females of
F . ( L .) sulcoa
sp. n.
; however, it differs in large irregular sensory pit of maxillary palp, lower PR and TRI value (maxillary palp with small rounded sensory pit, higher PR and TRI value in
F . ( L .) ansula
). The females of Australian species F .
( L .) tortuosa
described by
also resemble proposed new species especially by similarity with maxillary palp structure, but former have two spermathecae with hyaline punctation.

sec.title: Bionomics and Ecology
sec.p:
All the three proposed new species were fetched from different parts of Northern part of West Bengal using light trap.
Forcipomyia ( L. ) inflatistyla
sp. n.
were captured from Jayanti near the Buxa Tiger Reserve, a part of Eastern Himalaya in Alipurduar district (W.B.). This area is predominantly covered by long trees, at an altitude of more than
200 m .
Another two proposed new species,
F. ( L. ) ranula
sp. n.
and
F. ( L. ) sulcoa
sp. n.
were caught from the foothills of Eastern Himalaya in Kalimpong district (W.B.). Both species are inhabitant in mountainous forest cover area at an elevation of 1000–1200 m . Both regions are part of the Himalaya Biodiversity Hotspot.
